data: Fragment of a Latin inscription recording building works
A small fragment of a marble slab, broken on all sides, with a projecting element across the lower part, as if part of a base
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae

Th. Mommsen, Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars Posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae, Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum, Consilio et Auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae Editum, 10.2 (Berlin: G. Reimer, 1883)

sestertios C̅ m̅(ilia) quae rerem ? - - -
fragment of a latin inscription recording building works
ISic001664. Fragment of a Latin inscription recording building works

[---] 1𐆘 C̅ m̅(ilia) quae [rerem ? - - -]

[---]1C̅M̅(ILIA)QUAE[.........]

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

English translation

Italian translation

commentary

One of two fragments (the other is ISic003153), similar in palaeography and material, which may or may not be part of a single text (commonly edited as such), and which may or may not in turn be further fragments of the letter of Iulius Paternus (ISic000308). The fragments were considered by Mommsen and others (e.g. Manganaro 1989) to be part of the letter of Iulius Paternus of CIL 10.7024.i, published by Mommsen as 10.7024.ii and iii. However Manganaro (1959), and more recently Korhonen (2004), consider these two frr. to be part of a separate but contextually similar inscription, recording sums of money and building works linked to the port, and so probably also by Iulius Paternus, or under him. Korhonen correctly observes that it is not necessary that the two fragments CIL 10.7024.ii (ISic003153) and iii (this one) come from a single text; hence they are published separately here. Note that Manganaro 1989 reported this, the smallest fragment (CIL 10.7024.iii) to be lost, but it has since been rediscovered in the Museo Civico.
